prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not letting my parents access my phone history?
TL;DR mother wants me to put tracking app on phone I pay for, so she can 'see if I'm using time effectively'. 

I'm a college student and 700 miles away from home. Now where I live isn't a bad area per say, but every major town has it's rough spots. I have paid for my phone for the past few months after buying a little straight talk smart phone. Not a big deal right? I like having data that I can use and being able to talk to who I want. (Not forced to talk to people I don't like). When I want is a big deal to.  I don't have a car so I get on the weekend shuttle to Walmart for essentially everything. I don't leave the locked in campus. (We have walls that Trump dreams about y'all)(two lines of police intercept people coming in). She still says she wants me to download this app so she can she where I am at all times. Is this normal? I haven't lived with her for two years and she is known to be bipolar. Am I really disrespectful for not downloading an app for her to monitor my phone usage and tract my location?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so the user is asking if the person in the situation is wrong for not letting their parents access their phone history. Let me break this down.

The person is a college student living 700 miles away from home. Their mom wants them to install a tracking app on their phone, which they pay for themselves. They mention they don't have a car and use a shuttle, and their campus is secure. The mom is described as bipolar, and they haven't lived with her in two years.

First, privacy is a big factor here. The user is an adult, even if they're a student, and they've been living independently for two years. Parents usually don't have the right to monitor an adult child's phone without consent. The fact that the phone is paid for by the user adds to the argument that it's their device and their privacy.

The mom's reason is about tracking time usage and location. While parents might worry, especially if the child is far away, the method here is invasive. The user is in a secure campus, so maybe the mom's concern is overblown. Also, the mental health aspect of the mom being bipolar could mean her requests are more controlling or stem from her condition, which might not be healthy for the child to comply with.

The user is also setting boundaries, which is important. They're saying no to something that infringes on their privacy. There's no mention of the user being in danger or the mom having valid reasons beyond her own anxiety. In most cases, adults have the right to privacy, and parents can't enforce such monitoring without consent.

So, the answer would be B (No), the author isn't in the wrong. They're protecting their privacy and setting healthy boundaries, especially given their independent living situation and their mom's mental health issues.
